text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway. Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in.

text: Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step.

text: Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future –

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease-

text: Family Member: Shoot me now! Patient: I’m just wondering about a younger woman. Doctor: OH GOD! Family Member: OH! Doctor: Yeah, why don’t you find that one first, and - Patient: I guess I can cross that off my list (chuckles) Doctor: Yeah, I think. Patient: Oh did you get a new car yet? Doctor: I did. UNISON OH! Healthcare Professional: Oh you got a new car? Family Member: Oh no, you’re kidding. Doctor: Well I did because my daughter has taken mine. So I badly needed one. I mean I needed a set of wheels for sure.

text: Patient: No, no. Now, I’m saying uh, uh. Doctor: Did it start two days ago from today? Patient: Yeah! Doctor: But I didn’t give you the chemo. Patient: I know! Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s what I’m sayin’. So, Doctor: Yes. So, maybe it’s something Patient: That’s all, so what it does, is that a fact, can it happen like that? Can they do that? Like, is it, like I had diarrhea before, Doctor: Yeah. Are you taking any laxative or a stool softener or anything? Patient: Yeah. That’s what I’m sayin’ to you that stool softener don’t Doctor: Stop that then, because that’s, uh, worsening your diarrhea.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
